G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3, which grants the Housing Court jurisdiction over civil actions arising out of the landlord‑tenant relationship.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every lease or tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. (See G.L. c. 186, §14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716‑718 (1977); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every lease or tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. (See G.L. c. 186, §14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716‑718 (1977); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an “implied covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment” in the tenants’ leases and analyzes whether the landlords’ conduct breached that implied covenant, thereby causing constructive eviction. While the case does not explicitly say that *every* Massachusetts tenancy includes such an implied covenant, it proceeds on that premise without qualification and applies it in a standard residential context, supporting the general proposition that leases carry an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: "The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’ (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge)."

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every lease or tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. (See G.L. c. 186, §14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716‑718 (1977); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly applies and discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, treating it as an existing obligation in the landlord‑tenant relationship and analyzing whether the landlord’s omissions can breach it. While the case does not expressly state in so many words that "every lease or tenancy" contains an implied covenant, it proceeds on that premise, cites the statute, and explains the scope and operation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies, thereby supporting the proposition in context with Blackett and the statute.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant protects tenants from substantial interference with the beneficial use and enjoyment of their leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or failure to act. (Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102‑103 (1982); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997)).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly explains the meaning of ‘quiet enjoyment’ as the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy and notes that liability can be based on the landlord’s acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the premises, without requiring malicious intent. The court applies this to hold the landlord liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for allowing repeated flooding that interfered with the tenant’s use of the apartment, thus directly supporting the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from substantial interference caused by the landlord’s acts or failures to act.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute…. [Gem] violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The covenant protects tenants from substantial interference with the beneficial use and enjoyment of their leased premises caused by the landlord’s acts or failure to act. (Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102‑103 (1982); Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (1997)).
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, explaining that liability arises when a landlord’s negligent failure to act regarding known problems causes interference with the tenant’s rights. In doing so, it approvingly cites prior cases (including Simon v. Solomon) that treat a landlord’s failure to repair known defects—conditions that substantially interfere with use and enjoyment—as violations of § 14. Thus the case supports the general proposition that the covenant protects tenants from substantial interference with their beneficial use and enjoyment caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, though this case’s main focus is on the required fault standard (at least negligence).
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment)… Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”}

Watkins v. Montgomery County Hous. Auth..raw_text: Watkins v. Montgomery County Hous. Auth., 48 Mass. App. Ct. 59 (1999)
Watkins v. Montgomery County Hous. Auth..proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair the recurring water infiltration after notice constituted a willful and reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment. (See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102; Watkins v. Montgomery County Hous. Auth., 48 Mass. App. Ct. 59 (1999)).
Watkins v. Montgomery County Hous. Auth..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether a municipal tax collector may retain certain statutory fees or must pay them into the town treasury. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, water infiltration, quiet enjoyment, or willful and reckless disregard of a tenant’s rights. The case therefore provides no authority for the proposition about failure to repair water infiltration constituting willful and reckless disregard of quiet enjoyment.
Watkins v. Montgomery County Hous. Auth..relevant_excerpt: The defendants, the town of Blackstone and its board of selectmen, appeal from a judgment declaring that the plaintiff, who is the elected tax collector and treasurer of the town, is entitled to retain for her own use the fees and charges specified in G. L. c. 60, § 15 — primarily demand and warrant fees and charges for collection of delinquent local taxes. The judge decided that the plaintiff was entitled to the fees and charges… The judgment is reversed, and a new judgment is to be entered declaring that the collected fees, charges, and costs… are to be paid into Blackstone’s treasury.

Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.raw_text: Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.proposition: Repeated water leaks, persistent dampness, mold odor, and loss of use of part of the apartment are substantial interferences with Plaintiff’s tenancy and amount to a constructive eviction. (Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718‑719; Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973)).
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This portion of Hemingway is a concurrence/dissent focused on implied warranty of habitability and the relationship between housing code violations and rent obligations, not on constructive eviction. Justice Quirico explicitly notes that constructive eviction is not presented by the facts and is outside the scope of the issues being decided. Thus, the case does not establish that repeated leaks, dampness, mold odor, and loss of use of part of the apartment amount to a constructive eviction.
Hemingway v. Boston Hous. Auth., 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "Admittedly the rule suggested above does not cover the situation constituting a 'constructive eviction' of a tenant which is discussed in the court's opinion, but that is because the facts of the present cases do not involve such a situation. There is nothing to suggest that our courts which have heretofore given relief to a tenant who is the victim of a 'constructive eviction' will not continue to do so in an appropriate case."

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199‑200 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s statements that the condition was only “cosmetic” and his repeated refusal to perform proper repairs demonstrate bad faith and conscious disregard of his obligations under law. (See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199‑200 (1979)).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly finds there was insufficient evidence that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. The entire analysis emphasizes that considerations of fault and bad faith are irrelevant to the tenant’s right to rent abatement under the warranty of habitability. The case therefore does not stand for the proposition that statements minimizing a defect as “cosmetic” and refusal to repair demonstrate bad faith; instead, it holds that liability for rent abatement does not depend on bad faith at all.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability.… These contentions have no place in the framework established in Hemingway. Considerations of fault do not belong in an analysis of warranty.… The landlord may be correct in characterizing itself as an innocent party….”

Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 6.raw_text: Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 606, 609 (1998)
Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: The circumstances of this case constitute a willful violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14 and related jurisprudence. (See also Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 606, 609 (1998); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)).
Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 6.case_name: Rando v. Town of North Attleborough
Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: This case is a zoning/land use dispute concerning alleged spot zoning, contract zoning, and compliance with a municipal master plan under G.L. c. 40A and c. 41. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, residential tenancies, or G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment or willful violations thereof. Citing this opinion for the proposition that certain circumstances constitute a willful violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under c. 186, §14 is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the decision’s holding or reasoning.
Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 6.relevant_excerpt: Article 51 of the town meeting warrant, an amendment to the zoning by-law, was enacted by the defendant town of North Attleborough (town) after approval by the required two-thirds vote at the representative town meeting held October 23, 1993. The amendment changed approximately thirty-seven acres of land from a residential to a commercial zoning district. … As below, the plaintiffs’ principal arguments on appeal are that the amendment constitutes “spot” or “contract” zoning in violation of the Massachusetts Constitution and G. L. c. 40A, and that the town failed to follow its own “master plan” established pursuant to G. L. c. 41, § 81D.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The circumstances of this case constitute a willful violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14 and related jurisprudence. (See also Goshen v. Valeriano, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 606, 609 (1998); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords’ failure to provide heat, even where they lacked the financial ability to purchase oil, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court rejects intent and financial inability as defenses, emphasizing that liability attaches whenever the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is an interruption of the tenant’s rights. Thus, the case directly supports using it as authority for a willful (in the statutory sense) violation of quiet enjoyment in these circumstances.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”
